meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I mean, I think you pay a really large entropic penalty, right, for CO2 going from being free in the gas phase to confined on a surface. But like Chris said, I think it is a very unexplored kind of area. It's less obvious to me. I mean, usually enthalpy and entropy of absorption should be quite highly correlated, just the more strong of a binding site you have for the gas, the more constrained it's going to be on the surface. And so there's usually not that much you can really do, which is why maybe it makes sense just to focus on binding energy because the entropy is just going to kind of tag along. But that's where I think if you have more dynamic absorbents or absorbents and things that respond and are not just inert materials, but actually change in terms of their dynamics or structure as a function of CO2 partial pressure, then you open up opportunities for thinking about engineering entropy.
